name: Rahima Foundation
mission: Today, the world celebrates vast technological advancements, yet every 9th person suffers from food scarcity (1). The rate of food insecurity in the United States is even higher, standing at 11.8% (2). In the Silicon Valley, specifically, that rate more than doubles to 24.8%—making every 4th person food insecure (3). A total of 720,000 people out of 2.9 million Bay Area residents live with food insecurity (3).
theoryOfChange: Rahima Foundation states it provides a safety net to low-income community members through monthly groceries, rent and utility assistance, hot meals, and educational support to address basic needs and food insecurity.
zakatClaimEvidence: Found 'donate zakat' on https://www.rahima.org/zakat-rahima (https://www.rahima.org/zakat-rahima); Website mission/programs mention zakat (Source: https://www.rahima.org/donate)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Strong humanitarian service (+4)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 31/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, domestic poverty cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Publish a time-bound plan to deploy excess unrestricted reserves into mission delivery, while keeping a clear operating reserve floor.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

judge_issues.message: The impact rationale mentions strong financial stewardship but does not adequately address the high cost per beneficiary ($14222.07) or the lack of evidence and outcomes data, which significantly contributed to the low impact score of 19/50.

The amal_score_rationale mentions 'exceptional financial health' which is not entirely accurate. While the organization has strong financial metrics, the 'Financial Health' component within the Impact dimension received a score of 0/7 due to excessive working capital. This nuance should be reflected in the rationale.
Evaluation source domain 'unhcr.org' is not a known trusted evaluator
Zakat acceptance claimed but no evidence, URL, or direct verification provided

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: RAHIMA INTERNATIONAL FOUNDATION shows good alignment and limited impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Found 'donate zakat' on https://www.rahima.org/zakat-rahima (https://www.rahima.org/zakat-rahima); Website mission/programs mention zakat (Source: https://www.rahima.org/donate)

all_citations.claim: Rahima International Foundation holds a 96.0/100 rating and maintains a 95.3% program expense ratio.
The organization reported total revenue of $4,006,022 and holds 65.0 months of working capital.
The foundation offers Zakat-eligible donation options to support its mission of feeding the hungry.
The organization engages the community through volunteer opportunities in its soup kitchen and distribution programs.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The foundation earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial health and Zakat eligibility, balanced against a lower impact-to-cost ratio.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact data regarding long-term beneficiary outcomes
Lower overall impact score relative to total program costs

dimension_explanations.alignment: With a score of 31/50, the foundation shows moderate alignment by addressing urgent domestic poverty and offering Zakat-eligible giving options [1][3]. It maintains a high donor fit for those seeking direct service interventions in food security [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates strong financial stewardship with a 95.3% program expense ratio and a Charity Navigator score of 96.0/100 [1][2]. However, the impact score of 19/50 reflects a high cost per beneficiary and a need for more robust evidence of program effectiveness [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: Rahima International Foundation provides critical humanitarian relief through high-efficiency food distribution and educational support programs.
strengths: High fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 65.0 months of working capital
baseline_narrative.summary: Based in California, Rahima International Foundation is a Zakat-eligible non-profit dedicated to feeding the hungry and assisting financially insecure individuals [1][3]. The organization operates diverse programs including a soup kitchen, meat collection, and educational assistance for students in need [2][4].

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="13">board size of only 2 members</cite>, which is significantly below the recommended minimum for robust oversight.
While liquidity is a strength, <cite id="11">65.0 months of working capital in reserve</cite> is considered excessive and could be deployed more aggressively for mission impact.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization maintains audited financials but has not been fully vetted against all 20 BBB standards.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The foundation maintains high transparency seals to offset governance concerns.
risk_factors: <cite id="16">Revenue growth has declined by -5.2%</cite> over the last three years
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="13">critically small board size</cite>, which presents a risk to long-term organizational sustainability and oversight.

data_gaps: Small board size limits governance score
confidence.notes: Financial data is exceptionally strong and consistent across sources.

alignment.explanation: The organization has <cite id="9">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and a <cite id="1">33-year track record</cite> of serving the Muslim community's charitable needs.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be deepened by <cite id="3">expanding services to underserved geographies</cite> outside of the immediate Bay Area.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust the foundation's transparency as it holds a <cite id="12">Gold Seal from Candid</cite> and a <cite id="10">96/100 Accountability score from Charity Navigator</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="13">expand its board of directors</cite> beyond the current two members to ensure diverse oversight.

impact.explanation: The foundation is highly efficient, spending <cite id="7">100.0% on programs</cite>, but the <cite id="14">cost per beneficiary is high at $14,222</cite> compared to global education peers.
impact.improvement: Impact could be improved by <cite id="15">publishing a time-bound plan to deploy excess unrestricted reserves</cite> into direct mission delivery.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Documented Theory of Change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Supports large-scale humanitarian partners to extend reach

rich_narrative.headline: Rahima International Foundation provides critical humanitarian relief through high-efficiency food distribution and educational support programs.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors seeking to support local California Muslim communities through a highly efficient, zakat-eligible organization with deep roots.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure 95.3% of their donation reaches program services
Prioritize domestic poverty and hunger alleviation
Value long-standing community institutions with over 30 years of history
Seek to fulfill zakat obligations through direct food and education aid
giving_considerations: The organization holds very high cash reserves relative to its annual spending
Governance is centralized within a very small board
Impact is localized to specific Northern California counties
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking large-scale international systemic change or those who require a large, independent board for governance comfort.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization has a clear theory of change but lacks <cite id="15">external third-party evaluations</cite> of long-term outcomes.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The foundation provides immediate relief (food) and long-term support (education) to stabilize families and promote self-sufficiency.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the high cost per beneficiary translates into permanent life improvements.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Despite high reserves, <cite id="16">revenue has declined by -5.2%</cite>, suggesting a need for renewed donor support to maintain service levels.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by a <cite id="7">100.0% program ratio</cite> which exceeds the <cite id="17">peer median of 89.6%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focuses on relief for children in conflict zones
similar_organizations.name: KinderUSA

strengths.detail: The foundation directs <cite id="7">95.3% of its expenses to programs</cite> and spends <cite id="8">$0.00 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions.
The organization holds an <cite id="10">overall score of 96.0/100 from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting strong governance and transparency.
Serving <cite id="3">five major California counties</cite>, the foundation provides targeted relief to domestic poverty pockets.

strengths_deep_dive: Rahima International Foundation stands out for its extreme fiscal leanliness. With <cite id="11">65.0 months of working capital</cite> in reserve, the organization possesses a level of financial stability rarely seen in the nonprofit sector. This liquidity allows for consistent service delivery even during economic downturns. Furthermore, the foundation has earned a <cite id="12">Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, indicating a high level of public disclosure regarding its operations and mission.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">1993</cite>, Rahima International Foundation is a California-based humanitarian organization dedicated to <cite id="2">feeding the hungry and assisting the financially insecure</cite>. The foundation operates primarily in Northern California, serving regions including <cite id="3">Santa Clara, Alameda, and San Francisco counties</cite>. Their service model is built on direct intervention, providing <cite id="4">food distribution, soup kitchens, and meat collection</cite> to address immediate nutritional needs. Beyond emergency relief, the organization supports <cite id="5">students in their educational journey</cite>, aiming to break the cycle of poverty through academic assistance. Financially, the organization demonstrates a high commitment to program delivery, reporting <cite id="6">$4,006,022 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year. Remarkably, the foundation maintains a <cite id="7">95.3% program expense ratio</cite>, ensuring that every dollar of revenue is directed toward its core missions. This efficiency is further highlighted by a <cite id="8">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, suggesting that administrative and fundraising costs are covered through specific endowments or volunteer-led initiatives. The organization is <cite id="9">zakat-eligible</cite>, making it a significant vehicle for Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations through localized humanitarian work.
